Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Artificial Cell Membranes for Ultra-Pure, High Throughput Cellular Isolation

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
CBET-1351531
Berron

Cell-based therapies, where cells are transplanted to naturally restore biological function, represent an exciting future biomedical application. Critically, current techniques for high-purity cell sorting are time-intensive processes which lack the speed to satisfy the emerging widespread need for purified cells in research. The PI recently discovered a rapid cell isolation method in which batch size is virtually unlimited and nonspecific cells are undetected. The developed technology, Antigen Specific Lysis (ASL), selectively coats targeted cells in a temporary protective membrane, then destroys all uncoated cells to yield viable, purified cells. The proposed work will investigate fundamental mechanisms and relationships governing ASL in cellular isolation. This career development plan provides the foundation for a long term research program in the development ASL for the high speed isolation of rare biological products which yields a high-purity isolate from poorly-expressed markers. This research explores fundamental questions of cellular protection, and applies these findings to a cellular isolation technique which has the potential to reduce the presence of non-targeted cells to undetectable levels while sorting at exceptionally high rates.

Bioseparations will play a critical role in the future of the US economy, yet many postsecondary institutions lack sufficient staffing and expertise to offer these courses. A distance learning Bioseparations course will be developed to reach geographically disparate institutions, enabling a robust offering of Bioseparations materials to students several hundreds of miles away. This course will serve as a platform to probe the limits of collaborative learning techniques in distance learning environments. A significant limitation to Bioseparations education is a lack of online learning tools. ASL is built upon a foundation of diverse Bioseparations principles (e.g. lysis, filtration, sedimentation, adsorption), and this career development plan uses ASL as the centerpiece to online Bioseparations screencasts - short educational videos. These videos are popular among students, yet are currently limited in Chemical Engineering to core courses. The developed screencasts will be disseminated in collaboration with the NSF-funded, LearnChemE.com site, where the existing screencasts have had 1.6 million views in the last 12 months. Further, the screencasts will be critiqued and edited by the LearnChemE.com team, ensuring the highest quality educational products.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NSF award entitled, "CAREER: Artificial cell membranes for ultra-pure, high throughput cellular isolation" supported the development of the basic science underlying a new cell isolation platform. The research team leading this project discovered that thin polymer coatings will protect biological cells from harsh conditions. This research project focused on four main objectives to understand how and why these coatings protect cells, and the outcomes from each objective are described below.

The first objective was to determine the relationship between a thin polymer coating on the outside of a cell and the ability for the cell to survive in extreme settings. The team developed multiple coating chemistries and analyzed how materials enter and exit the coated cells. In the end, these coatings were acting like a filter: allowing water and salts to pass through but blocking damaging soap-like chemicals.

The second objective was to figure out how to remove the coatings when the harsh chemical is gone. The team developed two different strategies for this. One strategy caused the coatings to fall apart when exposed to light. The other strategy allowed the cells to naturally grow out of the cell. Both approaches provided healthy cells after the coating was removed.

The third objective was to find ways of putting coatings only on some cells and not others. This technological advancement permits the separation of interesting cells by protect them, while all other cells are destroyed. Antibodies, a type of protein created by our immune system, were generally the best approach to labeling cells for protection of targeted cells. This research project also determined how and why coatings formed with antibodies, and also developed several other strategies for putting coatings on cells.

The fourth objective was to develop online tools for educating engineering students on biological separations. This project resulted in the creation of nine online videos that have been viewed over 150,000 times. These videos have increased in popularity during the distance learning mode common during the COVID pandemic. Additionally, this project supported several educational presentations and videos on separations in the Kentucky distillery industry.

In all, this project advanced the basic science for a cell isolation strategy based on protecting some cells and killing others. This tool as a new way to isolate rare cancer cells from large samples of other non-cancer cells. This approach is a new exciting way of finding cells that are otherwise like a needle in a haystack. This opens up a new path to studying rare cells and figuring out how they work and what they do to our bodies.
